name: Magpie Goose
description: A highly distinctive, strikingly colored bird. Its head, neck, tail, and wings are black, the rest of its body white, and its legs, with short webbed feet, are orange. A notable feature is the knob at the base of the beak, present in adult birds.
proportions: Length 70–90 cm; wingspan 125–180 cm; weight 2–2.8 kg
attractions: Only distantly related to geese—scientists place it in its own family within Anseriformes. A gregarious species, it nests in colonies and gathers in flocks outside breeding season, sometimes numbering over a thousand. Its nesting habits are remarkable among Anseriformes: males often share incubation and chick-rearing with two females instead of one, and parents bring food to the young in the tip of their beaks, a behavior unique among waterfowl. Three parents improve provisioning and protection, increasing chick survival rates. In the wild, they can live over 30 years.
breeding: We have kept them since 1997, with the first chicks raised in 2008.
